newsitem.title: UK: Key dates in "mad cow" scare, beef war.
newsitem.headline: Key dates in "mad cow" scare, beef war.

text.p: Following are key dates in the history of Britain's "mad cow" beef scare:
1985 - Veterinarians see first signs of new cattle disease.
Nov 1986 - First diagnosis of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE).
June - Britain makes BSE a notifiable disease.
July 7 - Britain says all cows known to be infected with BSE will be destroyed as a precautionary measure.
June 13 - Britain bans human consumption of certain offal, including brain, spinal cord, thymus, spleen and tonsils.
Nov 13 - Ban on use of bovine offals in some animal feed.
March - EC Commission bans exports to the continent from Britain of cattle over six months old. This replaces the restrictions of July 1989 banning cattle born before July, 1988.
BSE is made a notifiable disease throughout the EC.
May 10 - Feline equivalent of BSE identified in a cat in Bristol, the first time a domestic pet is involved.
Sept 25 - Ban on use in animal feed of offal from cattle.
Feb 28 - France reports its first case of BSE.
March 12 - Medical journal The Lancet says death from Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) of a farmer whose herd had BSE was the first fatality involving contact with mad cow disease.
July 18 - EU approves ban on exports of meat, containing bones, from herds not free of BSE for six years instead of two.
Dec 7 - EU agrees to ease export curbs on beef from British cattle born since January 1, 1992.
Dec 14 - New controls imposed in Britain forbidding any use of the spinal column in "mechanically recovered meat".
Feb 6 - Five German states ban imports of British beef.
March 20 - British government admits for the first time that BSE can be transmitted to humans in the form of CJD.
March 21 - France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Sweden and Portugal ban imports of British beef, and Germany calls for a Europe-wide ban.
March 22 - Germany, Finland, Greece, Austria, Italy, Cyprus, Singapore, New Zealand, South Africa and Finland suspend imports of British beef.
March 23 - Fast-food giant McDonald's suspends the sale of British beef products in all its restaurants in Britain.
March 27 - European Union ban on British beef and beef products announced.
April 1 - Britain offers general and targeted culling of cows. It would involve killing all unproductive cows over the age of 30 months and destroying their carcasses.
April 11 - Netherlands begins to slaughter 64,000 imported British calves because of fears of mad cow disease.

April 14 - European Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler says he would have no worries about eating British beef and export ban was introduced not in interests of public safety but to prevent a collapse of the European beef market.
April 16 - France says it will destroy 70,000 British-born veal calves to prevent their meat from being sold because of fears it may be infected with mad cow disease.
April 24 - Britain to slaughter 40,000 cows to speed elimination of mad cow disease. Offer increased to 80,000 later.
May 21 - Prime Minister John Major says Britain will no longer cooperate in EU business until ban on its beef exports is eased and a framework for a complete lifting put in place.
May 23 - Britain starts policy of non-cooperation by blocking decisions at ministerial level.
May 24 - Britain issues proceedings in the European Court of Justice seeking the annulment of the beef ban.
June 5 - European Commission decides to lift ban on export of British beef by-products -- semen, tallow and gelatine.
June 11 - European Commission formally lifts export ban on British beef by-products.
June 19 - Framework deal for gradual lifting of ban includes Britain agreeing to cull up to 67,000 more older cattle.
June 21 - Deal agreed on lifting beef ban at Florence summit of EU leaders. Britain stops policy of non-cooperation.
July 23 - Scientists say mad cow disease can affect sheep.
Aug 19 - British coroner rules that a vegetarian who died of CJD caught it from eating beefburgers as a child.
Aug 29 - Scientists say BSE epidemic will die out by 2001.
Sept 11 - Major says Britain will review planned cull of cattle designed to eliminate mad cow disease.
